When I actually read the book (*The Leftovers*), I felt like true brilliance of the storytellingin addition to creating a world of characters that I cared aboutwas that its very explicitly stated that this isnt about resolving a central mystery. Way better. Until the most recent season, that is, when it took an absolute nosedive.

I don't see why you're taking this big issue of diversity -- "Yes, they don't always play major roles...The fact that there are plenty of shows on TV currently with black characters isn't enough, and it probably never be, because there's always be someone to whine about it." -- and shrinking it down to a small situation of a show-runner being told one of his characters he had written for a white guy has to be black.
Despite it happening all the time for a variety of reasons, the idea with external factors having a say in a creator's vision isn't the most palatable, I understand that. These shows, especially network ones, are far from pure distillations of a showrunner's vision, though. They are vast concoctions of that vision, the network's help (and yes, sometimes interference), the other writers in the writers room's ideas, the BUDGET. Even if you want to focus in on this one hypothetical you're talking about, a character assumed to be white being cast as a black for instance, I imagine that would be far from the only, let alone the largest compromise made.

Again, there's a huge disparity of roles and jobs going to minorities (and women) in Hollywood, in relation to their population shares. (1) That *does* effect the money because those people watch TV, too. (Empire and Fresh off the Boat and Black-ish and the like showed the TV industry that recently.)
If nothing proactive is done about this, how will that change? Do you think all these white guys running things are going to all of a sudden interact with a smaller proportion of white guys and start developing more (let alone a representative amount) of diverse stories for television? Or start being acceptably open to casting roles for minorities? (Remember, Caucasian is a race, too; that's a choice.)
Even getting aside from the human aspect of this, the equality aspect for a second; I want the interesting stories, and there are troves that haven't been told yet in the name of a lack of diversity. Just look at what *Atlanta* has done creatively. *Black-ish*. *Jane The Virgin*. *Orange is the New Black*. Etc... Over-proportionlly limiting stories on TV to the worlds of white guys is very limiting creatively, if nothing else.
This is far more than the idea of artificially shoehorning the topic of race or diversity into a show. That's a strawman argument if there ever was one.
edit clarity

Also, the issue here isn't some writer being told he or she has to start writing about things they aren't comfortable with. There is a lot involved with bringing a character to the screen, from the writers hired, to the directors, to the cast, etc... This giant issue of the lack of diversity in TV being reframed as a white writer being told he has to write about black culture isn't the least bit fair.

There's plenty of black people on television. **Yes, they don't always play major roles...**
Why is that OK? Why is that something that shouldn't be discussed? There *isn't* a representative amount of meaty roles in TV for minorities. This linked story is an interesting look at a micro world that spawns.
What's mock-worthy about this story?

WRITING.TITLE: How Fanfic Helps Black Women Create The Stories TV Still Can't Provide

All those guys in their ideal forms (i.e. in the eyes of the teams who like they the most, and pay them the most and get them) protect the rim. That's huge for a center in the NBA right now, especially if that guy can't step out and shoot the 3.
Baynes is a tough guy who tries hard, but he is limited physically and teams like to pay for projection.
Also, it will be a different market. Teams will have less cap space, and much less of them will need centers.

But the mystery, the intended cleverness: that *is* the show. That aspect of the show isn't ancillary. It would be one thing if it was just part of an otherwise compelling story or stories -- see: *Lost*. I think that's the issue many have with it, or at least myself. Too much of one's enjoyment of this show revolves around this puzzle being filled in.

I think we have to judge at the end of the season.
I hate this argument. Each episode has to offer something. Regardless of whether or not you respect the form of episodic storytelling (which *Westworld* is by virtue of its release schedule if nothing else, and thus should be held to that standard), I'm not investing a handful of hours into a show with the hope of some payoff two months from now. What are we, 6.5 hours into *Westworld* at this point?
If only there weren't like 10 storylines going on at once and we had more of that stuff.

I'm really enjoying it, much more than I thought I would. I thought I was growing tired of these Louie-esque shows, of which there are a number of now, but *Better Things* has broken through for me. I think it's the *joy* in it; it's a fundamentally optimistic show. It has found a lane that it's stayed in that's been a fun watch for me every week.
Dull and depressing? For my money this has been one of the more life-affirming shows I've seen recently. I think it's the opposite of depressing.
STORY. That's what's missing. Not plot, but human-level story. This show is a weird watch. (edit clarity)
